criticalESvalue 0.0.1

Equations

equations.Rmd

General

xx and yy are two samples with mean x¯\overline x and y¯\overline y and standard deviation sxs_x and sys_y. In case of paired samples, x1x_1 and x2x_2 are the two vectors (e.g., pre and post).

T-Test

Two-sample t-test

Assuming equal variances

t=x¯−y¯se t = \frac{\overline x - \overline y}{\text{se}}

se=sp2(1nx+1ny) \text{se} = \sqrt{s_p^2 (\frac{1}{n_x} + \frac{1}{n_y})} sp=sx2(nx−1)+sx2(ny−1)nx+ny−2 s_p = \sqrt{\frac{s_x^2 (n_x - 1) + s_x^2 (n_y - 1)}{n_x + n_y - 2}} The critical b=|x¯−y¯|b = |\overline x - \overline y| is calculated as:

bc=tcse b_c = t_c \text{se}

The critical tct_c is calculated finding the quantile of the tt distribution with ν=nx+ny−2\nu = n_x + n_y - 2 degrees of freedom.

nx <- length(x)
ny <- length(y)
tc <- qt(p = alpha/2, df = nx + ny - 2)
tc * se

The critical dd (effect size) can be calculated as:

dc=dcsp d_c = \frac{d_c}{s_p} The standard error of dcd_c need to be calculated using one of the available equations.

Some useful conversions:

Finding the pooled standard deviation from the standard error and sample sizes:

sp=se2nx+nynx+ny s_p = \sqrt{\frac{\text{se}^2 n_x + n_y}{n_x + n_y}}

Example converting tt to dd and the critical value:

n <- 100
x <- rnorm(n, 0.5, 1)
y <- rnorm(n, 0, 1)

fit <- t.test(x, y, var.equal = TRUE)

d <- unname(fit$statistic) * sqrt(1/n + 1/n)
c(d, effectsize::cohens_d(x, y)$Cohens_d)
## [1] 0.4414722 0.4414722

tc <- qt(0.05/2, n - 1)
abs(tc * fit$stderr) / effectsize::sd_pooled(x, y)
## [1] 0.2806107
abs(tc * sqrt(1/n + 1/n))
## [1] 0.2806107

Assuming unequal variances

t=x¯−y¯se t = \frac{\overline x - \overline y}{\text{se}}

se=sx2nx+sy2ny \text{se} = \sqrt{\frac{s_x^2}{n_x} + \frac{s_y^2}{n_y}}

The degrees of freedom are calculated as:

ν≈(sx2nx+sy2ny)2s14nx2νx+s24ny2νy \nu \quad \approx \quad \frac{\left( \; \frac{s_x^2}{n_x} \; + \; \frac{s_y^2}{n_y} \; \right)^2 } { \quad \frac{s_1^4}{n_x^2 \nu_x} \; + \; \frac{s_2^4}{n_y^2 \nu_y} \quad } νx,y=nx,y−1 \nu_{x, y} = n_{x, y} - 1

The critical value is calculated as the previous example. The effect size is:

d=bsm d = \frac{b}{s_m}

sm=sx2+sy22 s_m = \sqrt{\frac{s_x^2 + s_y^2}{2}}

One-sample t-test

t=x¯−μ0se t = \frac{\overline x - \mu_0}{\text{se}}

se=sxn \text{se} = \frac{s_x}{\sqrt{n}}

The critical value is calculated as usual. The degrees of freedom are ν=nx−1\nu = n_x - 1 and the effect size is:

d=x¯−μ0sx d = \frac{\overline x - \mu_0}{s_x}

Paired-sample t-test

t=μx¯1−x¯2sex¯1−x¯2 t = \frac{\mu_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2}}{\text{se}_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2}} sex¯1−x¯2=sx12+sx22−2rx1x2sx1sx2nx \text{se}_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2} = \sqrt{\frac{s^2_{x_1} + s^2_{x_2} - 2r_{x_1x_2}s_{x_1}s_{x_2}}{n_x}} Again the critical value is calculated as usual. The degrees of freedom are ν=nx−1\nu = n_x - 1. The effect size can be calculated in several ways. The dzd_z is the calculated dividing b=μx¯1−x¯2b = \mu_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2} by the standard deviation of the differences:

dz=μx¯1−x¯2sd d_z = \frac{\mu_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2}}{s_{d}}

sd=sx12+sx22−2rx1x2sx1sx2 s_d = \sqrt{s^2_{x_1} + s^2_{x_2} - 2r_{x_1x_2}s_{x_1}s_{x_2}}

Another version of the effect size is calculated in the same way as the two-sample version thus dividing by the pooled standard deviation:

dz=μx¯1−x¯2sp d_z = \frac{\mu_{\overline x_1 - \overline x_2}}{s_{p}} sp=sx12+sx222 s_p = \sqrt{\frac{s^2_{x_1} + s^2_{x_2}}{2}}

We can convert between the two formulations:

sp=sd2(1−r) s_p = \frac{s_d}{\sqrt{2(1 - r)}} sd=sp2(1−r) s_d = s_p\sqrt{2(1 - r)} The Figure below depicts the relationship between the effect size calculated using the two methods.

Clearly the critical value will depends also on which effect size we use.

Correlation test

The cor.test implements the test statistics based on the Student tt distribution.

t=rser t = \frac{r}{\text{se}_r}

ser=1−r2n−2 \text{se}_r = \sqrt{\frac{1 - r^2}{n - 2}} The critical rcr_c can be calculated using:

rc=tn−2+t2 r_c = \frac{t}{\sqrt{n - 2 + t^2}} The same can be done using the Fisher transformation that basically remove rr from the calculation of the standard error:

F(r)=12ln(1+r1−r) F(r) = \frac{1}{2} \ln \left(\frac{1 + r}{1 - r}\right) seF(r)=1n−3 \text{se}_{F(r)} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{n - 3}} Then the test statistics follow a standard normal distribution:

z=F(r)−F(ρ0)1n−3 z = \frac{F(r) - F(\rho_0)}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{n - 3}}} z=[F(r)−F(ρ0)]n−3 z = [F(r) - F(\rho_0)]\sqrt{n - 3}

The critical value is:

F(rc)=zcn−3 F(r_c) = \frac{z_c}{\sqrt{n - 3}}

In R:

gen_sigma <- function(p, r){
    r + diag(1 - r, p)
}

alpha <- 0.05
n <- 30
r <- 0.5
X <- MASS::mvrnorm(n, c(0, 0), Sigma = gen_sigma(2, r), empirical = TRUE)

cor.test(X[, 1], X[, 2])
## 
##  Pearson's product-moment correlation
## 
## data:  X[, 1] and X[, 2]
## t = 3.0551, df = 28, p-value = 0.0049
## alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  0.1704314 0.7289586
## sample estimates:
## cor 
## 0.5
se_r <- sqrt((1 - r^2)/(n - 2))
r / se_r # should be the same t as cor.test
## [1] 3.05505
tc <- qt(alpha/2, n - 1) # critical t
(r_c <- abs(tc/sqrt(n - 2 + tc^2))) # critical correlation
## [1] 0.3605197
pt(r_c / sqrt((1 - r_c^2)/(n - 2)), n - 1, lower.tail = FALSE) * 2 # should be alpha
## [1] 0.05

Now using the Fisher’s zz approach:

zc <- abs(qnorm(alpha/2))
(fr_c <- zc / sqrt(n - 3)) # critical F(r)
## [1] 0.3771952
tanh(fr_c) # fisher to r
## [1] 0.3602692
## r to fisher
# atanh(r)
pnorm(fr_c * sqrt(n - 3), lower.tail = FALSE) * 2 # should be alpha
## [1] 0.05
